body:
Based on following code one can't set a provider as an array. You would end up with `array{array, string}` on line 124 which is not a valid callable. So that e.g. needs to be removed.

https://github.com/cakephp/cakephp/blob/e6a6342dd238ea0eed656808262cfc02ef44a0f2/src/Validation/ValidationRule.php#L123-L125

> Either the API docs need to be updated, or the Cookbook... or both, detailing that providers don't necessarily have to be validation rule providers. Or maybe there should be an additional feature specifically meant for exposing arbitrary data to the validation rules.

This behavior was documented in cakephp/docs#3817 and because of that could be in use by a few applications. 

The code as it is documented *works* as long as you never try to actually use the provider as a rule provider. Given that this behavior is untested it is likely to break in the future. Would shimming bare arrays into ArrayObject instances be a path forward that folks would be open to?
Jeez, that's an awful hack and should never have been documented. I vote to get rid of it in 4.1.
We could add a deprecation when an object is not received. Userland code could start using the ArrayObject approach to keep similar behavior.

issue.title: Don't promote hackish usage of validation providers.
